description.text: This is a K8200/3Drag frame mounting clip with locking screws. It is based on my redesigned of the K8200 Frame Wire Clip On. Next step will be to use the clip in other designs there could benefit from the more secure frame clip. This design is experimental and may change, but usable as is. Inspired by K8200 FLAT Frame clip Velleman 3D printer.

Print one "Clip" and two "Screws".
Use high filling ration to make it strong and preventing it from breaking. In my tests I used ABS 0.3mm layer height 2 perimeters and 60% infill.
Here's a complete steam train, all nuts and bolts included!! choo chooo!

I started off by modelling the front big black front piece, then extruded out the cylindrical main body from it, added the chimney on top of the front piece, added the area underneath the front piece, then added the pointy piece at the very front and modelled the rest afterwards. The train is mostly dominated by cylinder origins.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

So I wanted to print out things for Christmas for my family to show off the printers capabilities, for fun, and save a little cash in the process.  I decided to design a phone holder that my dad could use with his new S4 (in or out of a case) in his truck.  
One caveat to this design, however, is that the back section (the stem and suction cup) come from a old dock I had for a droid razr.  I could have printed the stem and found an adequate suction cup but I had them laying around useless so I figured what the heck I'll design around those parts and I won't have to source the suction cup, after all I know this one works.  
The dock is adjustable and should fit a range of phones.  I designed the back piece to be able to accept #8 nuts so that #8 thumb screws or wing screws can be used to lock the sliding adjustable pieces in place once it has been determined what size is needed for your phone.  
Also the odd looking circular piece is the part designed specifically for the ball stem that came from my old dock.  A plastic nut screws onto that part and tightens around the ball stem.  This part will likely be useless to you.  I may design a separate piece, a ball stem similar to the one i already have, or something else to secure the dock entirely if requested.

black pla on a rep 2 only one part needed supports. 100% infill. added #8 nuts and wing screws as well as a bit of rubber padding where the cell phone will sit. I glued the nuts in place, the odd "nut adapter" in place and the back portion that has the tracks for the adjustment arms in place note back portion came from an old droid razr docking station. (this one http://tinyurl.com/motorola-dock) If requested I can design something to make this work without having to have those parts, but I didn't need it so I haven't worked on it yet.

description.text:
Push button to prevent quad-copter panels from coming apart on hard landings. The diameter of the shaft is 5mm.   
Update: Added weep hole to design to prevent airlock. One insert lock with weep hole per damper is fine.

comments.text: Thanks! These seems to work great. Much easier to install these than keep replace replacing zipties when I rebuild. In a crash, the vibration dampeners remain in place, though these locks pop loose. It's easy to push them back down and keep on flying.
comments.author: kd5ftn

comments.text: You're welcome! Happy to hear they're working out for you. Yes they do tend work themselves loose a little, but have not lost one in flight, as of yet. I think if I add a small weep hole through the shaft from top to bottom it may correct the problem from them sliding out slightly from the air trapped inside. I will have to test it out if my printer can print it being the part is small to start with. Printing from an SLA printer would be best and I don't have one. :(

author: Makershop

title: Dado Box (for use with openscad CSG ops)

description.text:
A repeatable Dado Box. One way to look at it is that this box can stack with itself on any surface. I use a loop like this to slice up big models in openscad: for(ix=[0:2])
{
for(iy=[0:2])
{
intersection() {
translate([ix dadoSize, iy dadoSize, 0])
placeMyModel();
translate([ix boxSize + ix dadoSize), iy boxSize + iy boxSize, boxSize / 2])
translate([baseOffsetX, baseOffsetY, baseOffsetZ])
placeDadoBox(boxSize, dadoSize);
}
}
}
}
} This will seperate a big model into many smaller models that fit together like puzzle pieces. My 2-D dado box (take off all the rotate([0, 90, 0]) shapes) works very well, is printable, and can be slid together easily... but requires a little bit of clamping and gluing to get a nice stable construction out of. The 3-D dado box however, not so much. You can't slide two neighboring pieces together without a weird diagonal slide, and the dado box itself isn't printable. I'm hoping someone wants to make a derivative of this that's printable, and I'm also hoping that if the box itself is printable, that means the items you make with it P.S. I actually am a veteran POVRay user, so I didn't need much of the tutorials to understand how OpenSCAD works... but because I have been reading the tutorials, and they are, in fact, awesome... I decided to tag it with openscadtutorial anyways.

Download. Print and watch as you violate the overhang rule. Print again with support and spend an hour cleaning out the slots. Bang your head a few times against your desk when it still doesn't slide together. Come up with a geometric proof that if it was printable, it would be slideable. Re-engineer to be printable. Print, slide, bask in the joy that is knowing you have satisfied one of MerlinJim's greatest, deepest, darkest, wishes. Alternately: Wait for me to upload the 2D version Use code like the following to make printable versions of big things: for(ix=[0:2])
{
for(iy=[0:2])
{
intersection() {
translate([ix dadoSize, iy dadoSize, 0])
placeMyModel();
translate([ix boxSize + ix dadoSize), iy boxSize + iy boxSize, boxSize / 2])
translate([baseOffsetX, baseOffsetY, baseOffsetZ])
placeDadoBox(boxSize, dadoSize);
}
}
}
}
}

title: Ultimaker fan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I created this thing in the hope to cool down our heated bed a bit faster after printing. Update: I did a real scientific experiment (n=1) and found that the printbed cools down from 70 to 30 degrees in 7 minutes. Without the fan this takes 26 minutes!!! This was probably the fastest project from idea to finished that I have every done. I imagined, designed, sourced parts, soldered the wiring all while my printer was busy printing another job(1h30). The 3d brackets to connect everything together worked surprisingly well for a first try. Project finished within 2 hours!

You'll need:
  • a big fan
  • two standard fan screws
  • optionally a switch
  • a 12V power supply
  • minimal soldering skills

Here's a version of AK Eric's dodecahedron made into a lamp.  It adds a two piece base, which, if desired, can hold a light socket inside the dodecahedron.  It has a few grill designs to choose from.  
Instead of the zip ties, it uses a printed clip to hold the pieces together.  
PLEASE NOTE:  This project involves mains wiring.  If you do not know how to do it safely, get help from someone who does or take a class.  You are responsible for the safety of anyone who uses something you build.

As noted in the description, this involves mains wiring. How to do this safely is outside the scope of these instructions. If in doubt about your abilities, consult with someone who has experience in electrical wiring or take a class. Be safe, sparkies. The other safety note is, because this is made of plastic, it will melt and create a fire hazard if an incandescent lightbulb is used. Only LED or CFL lighbulbs should be used, and this should be written permanently on the bottom of the lamp, since it could very well have more than one owner. Parts:
small/mini sized CFL or LED lightbulb. Ideally it should have a small enough diameter to fit through the hole in the pentagon piece, so it can be replaced easily.
3/8" (9.5mm) diameter all thread nipple, ~1" long (25mm). The length should be enough to stick into the socket securely, though the hole in the "base upper.STL", and get a nut on the bottom.
1 to 2 nuts for above
light bulb socket that threads onto the 3/8" threaded nipple, as low profile as possible. No switch is better because it saves vertical space.
Lamp cord, however long you want. I used 8' (3m) because 6' lamp cords are never long enough.
Plug for lamp cord
inline switch for lamp cord.
Sheet of frosted plastic, thin. I found this at a craft store.
super glue, gel type if possible. Tools:
Dremel/Rotary tool
Wire strippers
Screwdriver Instructions: Print 12x "pentagon piece V2.STL" If making it a lamp, the infill pattern you choose will be visible when the light is on. Print 11x "twisted grill v2.STL" or whichever grill design you prefer. When placing the object in your slicer, note how the part's corner's sides are tapered to go with the pentagon piece. Decide whether you want the shiny, bed side finish to face outward, or the rough, 3D printed texture of the top. I liked the rough texture better, so printed it upside down, with the taper spreading outward. A concentric infill works well with the "twisted grill v2.STL" Print at least 30x of the "clip V2.STL". Best to print some extras (like 8x) in case any break or don't print right. With these, the infill setting is important, a 100% concentric infill made mine come out right. Rectangular infill makes them brittle. If they have no infill, they seem too bendy with one perimeter, though if you have a smaller nozzle than me (.5mm) you may be able to make two perimeters and no infill, and make them come out strong and flexible. With the right infill setting I could use PLA and not have them break when snapping them in. Print 1x "base top.STL" and 1x "base bottom.STL" Glue, screw, or better, friction weld (with some straightened filament in the dremel) the corners of the 12 grill pieces to the 12 pentagon pieces. Here are two articles on friction welding, it is much stronger than glue. http://www.fabbaloo.com/blog/2014/2/12/friction-welding-your-3d-prints
http://makezine.com/projects/make-34/skill-builder-finishing-and-post-processing-your-3d-printed-objects/ Be sure the little square slots for the clips do not get covered up. Note the taper to the grill piece corners, it should continue the taper of the pentagon piece's side. The dodecahedron won't fit together all the way if they are upside down. There should be one pentagon piece left over, with no grill. This will be the bottom, which the base snaps into. If you want to use some frosted plastic to diffuse the light from the lightbulb, cut it into the shape of the grill, except the corners can be trimmed off. Cut 10x of them. Leave the plastic off the grill piece that will be on top of the dodecahedron, to let out any heat generated by the lighbulb. Glue them to 10x of the grills. Assemble the dodecahedron with the clips. Start with the grill without plastic on top, work around the top and sides, but don't put the bottom piece, the one with no grill, in yet. Wire the light socket, secure it to the threaded nipple, thread the "base upper" on the wire, and then the nut. Tighten everything together. Glue or friction weld the "base bottom" to the "base top". The lamp wire goes through the slot in the "base bottom". It may take some pressure when glueing or welding the two together, because the wire in the slot may try to push the pieces apart. Snap "base upper" into the last pentagon piece, that has no grill. Be gentle if you're using PLA, you can use a medium sized flathead screwdriver to gently push the hooks in, to snap into the pentagon piece, by working back from one corner. Screw in the lightbulb. Clip this lamp with the last pentagon piece to the dodecahedron.

Assembly:
The chain clips are designed to lock quite strongly so the segments don't come apart easily, however this makes it a bit more difficult to assemble. PLA will probably snap if you try to force the segments together. ABS might be flexible enough but I haven't tested it. Starting with the largest body segment, heat the wall of the arch enough to soften the plastic slightly (about 60-70 Celsius for PLA, hotter for ABS). You don't want the plastic to melt, just to soften. If you have a heated print bed that's perfect, otherwise a hair dryer should do the trick. Place the head piece on a flat surface and firmly press the heated body segment down over its locking pin. This will slightly deform the tabs on either side of the arch. Quickly turn the model over and, while the piece is still warm, press the tabs back into shape (a small flat-head screwdriver will be helpful). Heat the wall of the second largest body segment and use the same technique to attach it to the other two. Repeat this procedure all the way down to the tail. Printing:
I've split the model into two prints, which are sized to fit onto a RepRap Huxley print bed. The pieces can possibly be rearranged to fit into a single Mendel print. The scale given in the STL files will produce an assembled Comura of 19cm long and 9.5cm wide at the head. I would suggest scaling this model to 100% or greater, as the chain clips might be too weak at smaller sizes. Some of the spines might come out a bit poorly and need some TLC to tidy them up. Printing at a slower speed might help. The spines are the last thing to come out of the printer, so it may help to use use a small fan to cool the plastic more quickly as it exits the nozzle during this last part.

Basics
=====
This set of test prints is designed to assist you in the calibration of build platforms. These prints attempt to balance time and plastic used with getting decent results. In short, it should be a more efficient method. Included

There are two sets of calibration prints included here. The first set is for build plate leveling. These are the flat squares. They are intended to print above the build platform thumbscrews. Please see below for details.
The second set is a set of concentric cylinders. These are intended to help you adjust belt tension on your MakerBot Replicator 2. Again, please see below for details. Updates
====
Update 4/5/13: Added circle calibration print. After having circles that came out as ellipsoids, I created these as a simple test of belt tightness.

Prelude
==
I'm going to assume you know how to download and print objects - there is nothing different or special about doing so with this object. Instead, here are directions on calibrating a bot with it. These directions are loosely based on those given by MakerBot if you contact them with calibration issues. The STL files included are for the MakerBot Replicator 2, as that is what I have. The OpenSCAD script used to generate the STLs is included, so you can tune it yourself (or to your printer). Build Plate Leveling
==
First off, I recommend going through the MakerBot's built in calibration. That will get you close enough for these to be useful.
Next, print this object on medium resolution. If the printed plastic is cylindrical and has gaps between the lines at any of the three test points, the build platform needs to be raised at that point. If the plastic extruded is thin, squashed, intermittent or not extruded, the platform is too high at that point - lower it. Repeat until you get plastic where you can see the individual lines, but the overall print is flat and has no gaps.
Finally, repeat on fine quality until satisfied. Circle Calibration
==
I was printing some parts which depended on circles coming out.. well, circularly. They weren't. This file was put together as a test case for a bug report, but can also quite easily be used to test if the issue exists and/or has been corrected.
In short, if the result is not circular, you need to adjust the belt tension on the X and Y axes. See http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=76XaGlyG0Z0 and http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l1FWj-ZHEVA for how to adjust this.
What MakerBot doesn't tell you is how tight to make the belts. To quote Nick at MakerBot support:
"There isn't really a precise measurement when adjusting your Replicator 2's belts. A good test would be to tighten until they feel taut, then attempt to print a circular or cylindrical model, and see if you start to get better results." I found simply getting things as tight as was reasonable and I was comfortable with was sufficient. So why is this a better calibration print?
==
Quite simply, this print is better because it allows you to independantly adjust each of the three thumbscrews on the Replicator 2 independantly, therefore making calibration easier. This means fewer prints, means less plastic used and you printing new shiny toys earlier.

description.text: Drum roll please ~ It’s time to release our new Super Secret Crackers! We've created three extra special designs that join our 2013 Super Secret Cracker collection. As before, the crackers print with a hidden gift inside that's only revealed when you snap the cracker in half. We think these are our best designs yet. Can you guess what’s in the crackers? No peeking now... New Super Secret Crackers is our little gift to you this season. Make Merry and have a wonderful holiday. x

We've created a 'Starter Test Kit' to help tune in your machine before going for the full build. You might want to check your bed adhesion, bridging, retraction and slicing for fine features. Print at ~0.3mm layer height, 2x shells (/perimeters) and 2-5% infill (although should be self-supporting at 0%). Each cracker requires ~34g of material (~4m of 3mm / ~12m of 1.75mm filament). Printed in gorgeous Faberdashery Pearly White^ combined with Smoky Black^, Dark Sapphire^ & Glacial Blue^. The translucent PLA gives a nice hint at the contents :) The Crackers need to be gently eased off the build plate to save them breaking too early and spoiling the surprise. We suggest carefully removing the finished Cracker with Mole Grips (or equivalent) at the base. For the ultimate festive finish print in two colours, changing filament at 30mm and 70mm layers (Use Z-Pause if your machine supports it). There are three different surprises in each cracker, that all print-in-place. Once you've pulled your crackers you can turn the ends around, string them together through the special holes and hang on your tree as a cracker decoration!

description.text: The Hoover Air Cordless (http://aircordless.hoover.com) offers up to 50-minutes of runtime from two Extended Runtime LithiumLife Batteries. remixed_from.title: Parametric Herringbone Gear Set for Greg's Accessible Wades

title: A bowden geared extruder for Rostock - based on Gregs

description.text: This is a geared extruder for Rostock and other printers, it uses 1.75mm filament and 4mm Pneumatic fittings for PTFE tubes as the Bowden element.

Print out and assemble with Herringbone gears (any to fit Greg's design) and use the 1.75mm filament guide here. Flip the design if you want it mounted the other way around or if you are planning a dual bowden extruder setup. I have been running it for about 4 months, works really well - and can mount to t-slot frames if you like. Sketchup file added so remix it if you like. BOM as requested - It's very similar to any of the other Greg's / Wade's Extruders on Thingiverse -
To print the 1.75mm Version - So you need to print the two models here. And a set of Gears - I recomend using the Parametric Herringbone Gear Set for Greg's Accessible Wades - by Triffid Hunter - thing:10707 The hobbed bolt is a standard 8MM type, it should be the most common available from many places - check eBay. Some long M3 screws for the pressure block springs (about 55mm long) 1 x 35/40mm M3 screw for the pressure block. Two springs or silicone pads. 3/8" or 10mm Pneumatic fitting to accept 4MM PTFE Tube. A length of PTFE tube 4mm OD 2mm ID 4 x M3 x 10mm bolts for the motors and small gear M3 nuts x 5 M8 washers - to space the hobbed bolt correctly M8 Locknut I think that's it? Or use the Version by Woodsmoke if you use 3mm Filament.

comments.text: HyperAir, this is fairly typical of the Greg's Wade-style extruder.  it doesn't matter how it's mounted, the same problem exists with flexible filament.  I have NinjaFlex and it doesn't feed well through my Greg's extruder.  Simply too flexible for the size of the gaps around the hobbed bolt, and no way to make it feed reliably.  Just this morning I gave it another shot using a very slow print speed as well as a slow filament feed with my 1.75mm NinjaFlex.  Jammed every time right at the hobbed bolt.  There are some less flexible filaments out there but I haven't tried any of them.  Perhaps one of these days.  If anyone out there successfully uses flexible filament with the Greg's Wade-style extruder then please post the info on how you get it to work.
comments.author: hyperair

comments.text: I drilled out the hole with a 4mm drill bit and forced my PTFE Bowden tube into it. Then I cut the shape of the hobbed bolt and the bearing into the top of the PTFE, so my filament is fully supported all the way in. https://goo.gl/photos/mWG7aaC4irszXcn26 and https://goo.gl/photos/hDqzWZg3xm9G7GhU8 show how I did it. I can now print Nylon pretty decently on this setup. Not absurdly fast, but decent.

My understanding of your original comment was that you were specifically addressing flexible filament, for which I had the same problem.  I haven't tried the flexible stuff on my delta yet.  I'll get to that eventually.

title: Parametric Filament Spool Hub with 608ZZ bearing

description.text:
This is a parametric filament spool hub with 608ZZ bearing which easily slides in and out of an 8mm aluminum tube, or smooth or threaded steel rod, as it does not require a nut. As long as it is correctly dimensioned, it just snaps in place in the center of your filament spool. The 608ZZ bearing guarantees a totally frictionless operation.  
This is my own design, remixed from thing #545954 by mateddy (James Lee),  redesigned from thing #27139 by QuantumConcepts (Josh McCullough) and also inspired by a brilliant design by labidus (Sylvain Rochette), thing #596838. I tried to combine the best ideas from each design!  
OpenSCAD source is available so it can be further remixed.  
Update 23/12/2014: reinforced the "petals" and code cleanup.

Printed here in PLA with 35% infill, 0.2mm layer height, 0.6mm walls and top/bottom layers.  
Measure the diameter of the hole of the filament spool and also the depth of the walls of the hole, and input these parameters in Customizer, it will generate a correctly dimensioned part that should just snap in place in the center of your filament spool.  
Requires one 608ZZ bearing, just press the hub over the bearing on a flat surface, preferably just after the hub has been printed and the PLA is still warm and has not contracted. It's a tight but perfect fit.  
Obviously you need a pair of these per filament spool.

So I tried printing a couple with 9mm (default) and a couple with 7mm, and they both worked great, but I prefer the 7mm as that provided a much better grip onto the spool and is less likely to slip. I just don't get the "depth of the walls of the hole" thing. And as syue87 asked a couple years ago, what's that little half circle in the design for?
On a more positive note however, I will say that I printed a bunch of these and my spools now spin if I blow on them. Friction is almost completely gone. But most importantly they take up very little space and I'm able to place 4 spools next to one another on one rod. Absolutely love it!

remixed_from.title: RPi and camera support for Printrbot Simple Maker's Kit (1405)

title: RPi and camera support for Printrbot Simple Maker's Kit (1405) version 2

description.text: The Printrbot Simple Maker's Kit is a wonderful small 3D printer with loads of potential. Octoprint has a special distribution for the Raspberry Pi called OctoPi which allows one to load STL parts, print and make time lapse videos via local network and free your computer from the burden of being attached to the printer for while it's printring. To mount parts to the printer more securely I made some supports that attach to the existing screws on the printer, the screws are long enough to hold the supports and still reach the nuts. The support for the RPi is for the model B, not the more recent B+. The stock RPi camera cable isn't long enough so I ordered a longer one from DealExtreme (although it needs to be modified). The camera has its focus set to infinity by default you need to break the glue inside it by rotating the lens a little bit to adjust the focus as needed, otherwise you'll get a very blurry image. Since the Printrbot USB port is so close to the RPi USB port I also ordered a tiny micro-USB cable. To complete the set I added a USB Wi-Fi dongle on the RPi so I can control it wirelessly from anywhere in the house from any device. The camera can be oriented and since the version 1 is now attached on the print bed making videos much better. The cable management has also been improved with, again, parts that use the existing screws to hold them securely in place. To improve the field of view of the camera, which is quite close to the part, I used a cheap camera lens for smartphones. It's not required, but does improve a little bit. It also holds the camera in place making the M2 screws and nuts unnecessary. Here's an example of what can be recorded with this setup.

description.text:
Jig Saw Puzzle with elephant design, birds and words.
****Can be personalized**

This is a Christmas Present for my friend and it is designed with stuff that she likes so if you don't like the design you can always delete the layers for the designs and create your own.   
What I did was: I took a picture of puzzle pieces and layered it over the work plane. I then traced the puzzle pieces with a pencil at 0.001 point so when I printed it it would vector it. I locked that layer and hid it so I could draw. I created a new layer and pasted a picture I liked of a tribal elephant. I liked the layout of the elephant so I created a new layer and on that layer I used a paintbrush to paint in the outlining shapes and I creating my own designs on a majority of the inside. I then grouped the whole drawing. To fill in the spaces left I live traced pictures of the birds. The designs are in red so it wouldn't blend in with the black of the puzzle pieces outline. The puzzle piece layer was moved so it would be in front of the designs so it would be completely vectored into pieces.  
When everything was finally complete I printed it out. Some of the edge pieces the corners didn't cut all the way but I was easily able to break them apart. It made no difference when I put the puzzle together.

This set is complete to let you build a outlet system for your JBL ProFlow pump.  
It is composed of 4 main part types  
Connectors between pump and system  are named with prefix JBL_ every other part is for the system itself.  
Also I added an adapter in different sizes to attach a hose to the system and a diffusor which allows you to attach a air hose (6mm/4mm).  
If you need a different form of it which is missing leave a comment I try to creat it ;)  
This allows you to print an outlet system for your need.

I printed it with a layer thinkness of 0.3mm the pieces are a very thight fit. Make sure you connect them from beginning like you want them because they will not get apart after joining them.  
In case you have the need to disasseble make 2 axial cuts on the outer shell simaler to the connector. Then parting them will be possible. Check the picture of the straight part with holes there you can see what I mean.  
In the two pictures you can see a series how they could be joined.

title: Lighting Element
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is 3D printed bracket for an inexpensive light-bulb socket (see part list). The snaps and dimensions are compatible with the other objects I've tagged with "Elements" This thing is intended for use in a truncated-icosahedral lamp, once I find some affordable low wattage CFLs. I designed the part by minor modification to the circular elements OpenSCAD script : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5859.

Print both parts. 
Trim the extra plastic off the hinges.
Test fit with the bulb socket. The socket should rest tightly in the piece, flush with the inner surface. If the socket is raised, the bracket hole is probably too tight. Trim away plastic until the bulb socket can rest flush in the bracket.
Glue ( I used gorilla super-glue ) the socket into the larger bracket. 
Glue the hexagonal plate over the socket, making sure to affix the plate to both the bulb socket and the printed bracket. 
Let dry. 
Assemble creatively with other compatible parts.
The sockets have a simple way of clamping onto electrical wire. The part specifies 12 to 14 gauge wire, but I used 16 gauge since that's what was available. Once your object is assembled, you can wire and power it up ( but be careful with 110AC ).
A few pitfalls I've noticed : 
The snaps, individually, are weak. The snaps, as a whole, are ridiculously strong -- stronger than the super-glue. 
It is really important that the socket be flush in the main bracket so that the hexagonal plate makes full contact with both the socket and the bracket : this is a big source of structural integrity.
I would be shy of using high-wattage bulbs in these sockets, since ABS softens at a mere 100C and PLA even colder than that.
note on hinge clearance : The hinges can sometimes be a little tight. Make sure the first layer isn't pressed too far into the build platform. A compressed first layer will propagate up and make part of the hinge wider, decreasing the clearance. These parts are designed to fit tightly and may require pliers to assemble. If all else fails, removing some of the pins on the hinges can make assembly easier.

description.text: I built this last year with a MakerBot 2X.  it worked great.  I had to have a raft on it, but I think I could build it now without the raft.  Don't try to use supports, or you'll be taking the supports off for ages.

If you have a injured, weak or sick fish and you need to separate him form the others this floating tank can be placed inside the aquarium.
The part itself is designed to float so you can put the fish inside. Due to the design the water will be exchanged like in the rest of the aquarium.
This helps to keep the fish from stress and accelerate heeling. Note: Infectious diseases should not be handled with this piece since it will not remove the infected fish from the aquarium leaving the chance the disease spreads.

I have not yet printed one but due to the calculations I have done they should float perfectly the bigger one even better then the small one.  
Also when you print them with the side with the holes in it on your printerbed you will not need any supports to print.

author: jbock

description.text:
This is a model loosely based on the R-7, the rocket which launched the Sputnik satellite.  Derivatives of this rocket are still used today and are currently used to transport humans and supplies to the International Space Station, amongst many other uses.  On the negative side, this was also the world's first ICBM.  
The model is designed to be spiral-printed.  The STL file is of substantial resolution, so feel free to zoom in!  
Minor update: I've added a second STL which contains a model representing the engines.  Print it 'normally' (not spiral) and glue it on the bottom of the main model.  Both pieces are modeled in the updated scad file.
Another in my series of project using the small FA-130 Size motors. Read More about it here: http://www.skimbal.com/explorations-and-speculation/2014/12/22/small-motor-creations-6-orbital-gearboxes

comments.text: Love the designs.  Any chance you could share the design files? I have some small pager motors I want to try in a design like this.
comments.author: pyrophreek

description.text:
Print a tree topper that could never be injection molded! Print two of these and then put them together with the pegs provided and glue.  
I recommend using a translucent filament and putting tree lights inside for the best effect.

Makerbot does a decent job of building supports for this, even though they are a bit difficult to remove. I ended up having to print it on an MB2, because the "smart" extruder (no comment), actually 2 of them can't extrude anything for more than 10 minutes without jamming. This results in a tree topper that still looks too small on my tiny tree. I'll post a file optimized for a Type A as soon as I test the print.

comments.text: Great looking model, but it looks like there are some issues with the uploaded file, in which the stem (or part that goes on the tree itself) isn't flat on the build plate.  I failed in the first print attempt because of this, and modified the file to have it flush with the print bed and then added supports to attempt a reprint.  The reprint did much better, but still had a lot of issue (I'm guessing it's curling of the ABS I'm using as it cools during the print).  I'd love to hear any recommended settings you've used, but I'm bound to run into some issues due to the fact that I'm new to the world of 3D printing world right now.  Thanks for sharing the model though!

description.text: This is a very good laptop stand for 15.6 inch models.

comments.text:
I know the common trend to make keyboards rise away from the user is popular.
But, the reasons keyboards were made to do that was NOT for ergonomic purposes but for mechanical ones (to make room for the typewriter mechanism). It is actually Less ergonomic to have the keyboard rise away from the user. If one were to have a slope then the rise should be toward the user to lessen the strain from flexing the wrists into that unnatural position.

Most of our users do use a laptop stand, but also have an external keyboard and mouse...
The reason for the stand (or sometimes only a riser) is to get the laptop display at the same height as the external display.

title: Replicator 2 extruder replacement with no overheating issues

description.text:
As many friends here, I was suffering overheating problems in the rep2 extruder mod downloaded from thingiverse. This heat causes a deformation in the extruder pieces and the system starts to lose strength and print worse with time. Bored about this problem (I replinted 4 or 5 extruder mods) I decided to design an easy and cheap way to replace the extruder with same printing results as a new extruder mod but with no deformations due overheating. I bought a plunger from farnell:
http://es.farnell.com/jsp/search/productdetail.jsp?SKU=1378331
and I used an spring from vanel I had at home:
https://www.vanel.com/spring-details.php?lang=spanish&ref=C.081.125.0100.I&sessionid=87222222128513e06795f3a9966294491120580088288434 I redesigned the extruder system to fit the spring and used the ball (only the ball) from the plunger bought in farnell. As the spring was longer than needed I had to increase 2mm the size of the "casing" but as there was space it was no problem. It works very weel and the heat didn't cause any deformation that causes to start to print worse. Hope you will enjoy!

description.text:
This is a small portuguese "Tuna" tambourine, made for a friend. You can add a couple of M6 washers to any of the columns around the circle, this will give it SOUND!
I add a little bit of adhesive to the top, a keychain and some fabric stripes, since it gives it a better look.
If you want to know more about portuguese Tunas:

Here's a few more info on wiki about Portuguese Tunas.
http://goo.gl/UvS4av This is Tuna Templária de Tomar, performing a Tuna's tambourine song.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C6wU3W-un3s&feature=youtu.be
NOTE: This is not an exact scale replica.

Layer Height - .2mm
Shell Thickness - 1.0mm
Density - 20%
1st Layer Thickness - .3mm No support needed IMPORTANT!
If you're planning to add M6 washers, you'll need to do it while printing.
I didn't paused my printer, instead I just dropped the washers after the hot end passed by, keep in mind that you need enough layers to cover the M6 washer height, otherwise the hot end will probably get stuck in them!!!

description.text: This is a 3D-Printable "Useless Machine". Hit the switch, and the useless machine uses a tiny arm to switch itself back off. These are popular gag gifts, and make for a great desk toy! You can print this one yourself, and the parts are really cheap. Check out the instructions for a parts list and assembly steps. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z_3iLXr7oS0&feature=youtu.be
1x Micro Gearmotor

1x DPDT Toggle Switch
1x SPDT Limit Switch
2x 1-AA Battery Box

1x M2.5 Metric Tap
1x M3 Metric Tap
1x Tap T-Handle
10x M2.5x10mm Machine Screw
6x M2.5x8mm Machine Screw
1x M2.5x5mm Machine Screw
2x M3x14mm Machine Screw

24AWG Wire
Soldering Equipment
Metric Hex Wrenches/Allen Keys

NOTE: There are two images in the gallery to help with assembly. One is for the electrical schematic, the other is to show how parts are oriented inside of the shell.
  • Use a knife to cut the mouse ears off of the base, top, shell, and hatch. Use some high-grit sand paper to smooth out the cuts.
  • Tap all of the 3D printed parts using the M2.5mm Tap. The shell has through holes all the way through, but you only need to tap about 8mm down on each side. DO NOT tap the holes in the top plate that will be used to attach the hatch.
  • Tap the SPDT lever switch holes using the M3mm tap.
  • Solder the components using the schematic shown in the picture gallery.
  • Attach the motor to the base plate using the motor bracket and 4 of the M2.5x8mm screws. The side of the motor with the electrical terminals should be on the same side of the base plate as the slot. The shaft should be pointing inwards on the base plate. Don't tighten it too much or it will restrict the motor from turning.
  • Attach the arm to the motor shaft. Use the M2.5x5mm screw as a set screw to attach the arm to the D-type shaft of the motor.
  • Attach the SPDT Lever Switch to the Kill Switch Mount.
  • Attach the Kill Switch Mount to the base plate slot using 2 of the M2.5x8mm screws. 9. Adjust the position of the mount in the slot so that the motor turns off when the arm is just about to touch the base plate.
  • Attach the shell to the base plate using 4 of the M2.5x10mm screws.
  • Attach the hatch to the top plate using 2 of the M2.5x10mm screws. Remember, these two holes should not be tapped. This allows you to tighten the screws into the holes without having to have the screw head be flush against the inside of the hatch. The idea is that the screws should be held tight by their threads, allowing the hatch to move freely. You may need to do a little sanding on the edges of the hatch to get it to move freely and rest flush on the top plate.
  • Attach the DPDT Toggle Switch to the top plate. Remove the washers that the switch comes with; you only need the one nut to fasten the switch to the top plate. Make sure you orient the switch in the correct direction.
  • Attach the top plate to the shell to complete the assembly. Obviously make sure you put some AA batteries in the battery box and place the box inside of the shell beforehand.

description.text:
Well, I have a lot of batteries but the dispensers/hoppers I've tried  did not really fulfil my needs, so I designed my own from scratch but was inspired by jgillick's dispenser (thing 310472)  
These 2 dispensers each hold 18 batteries.  
The AAA dispenser clicks on top of the AA dispenser.  
The batteries can slide out from the side, so it does not matter if one side of the dispenser is blocked by something.  
Both can be used as separate dispensers as well

Included now is a version 2 of the dispensers.  
Version 2 is extendable and still stackable.  
The extension hold 16 batteries. Print more if you need more and stack them...

So, If you have many batteries, download and print:
batterydisp_AA
batterydisp_AAA If you have too many batteries, download and print:
batt_disp_AA_v2
batt_disp_AAA_v2
batt_disp_AA_v2_extension (one or more)
batt_disp_AAA_v2_extension (one or more)

No support needed
0,2 mm layer commended but 0,3 mm gives good results as well.
Better printer adjustments --> Better parts fit

comments.author: Hellraiser76

comments.text: Printed on my DaVinci at 20% infill and 200 microns (0.2 mm). I'm using Prototype labs filament since my printer has custom firmware so I can do away with the awful proprietary filament, but that shouldn't matter too much. Whenever I print something that needs to hold up any weight/will be used a lot I always use at least 20% hexagon infill. If it still doesn't work, try using Slic3r. The exploit doesn't need you to modify any firmware, But does need to you switch around some code in the 3W file that is exported. It's not too hard, but I wouldn't do it if you don't have too much experience with printers and G-code.
